subject: Law
title: Roman Law and Its Legacy
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Roman Law and Its Legacy.

hook.text: Rome fell 1,500 years ago. Its legal system lives on in every civil law country on Earth.

buildup.text: Roman law developed over centuries, from the Twelve Tables (450 BCE) to Justinian's Corpus Juris Civilis (534 CE).

discovery.text: It introduced concepts still used today: contracts, property rights, legal persons, and due process.

twist.text: Justinian's codification preserved Roman law through the Dark Ages. Medieval scholars rediscovered and spread it.

climax.text: Most of continental Europe, Latin America, and parts of Asia base their legal systems on Roman foundations.

punchline.text: Rome's empire crumbled. Its law is still the foundation.

quiz.question: What was Justinian's major legal achievement?
options: Codifying Roman law into the Corpus Juris Civilis
